data.title: kevin: don't run sanity check on debian
data.body: This improves the dirty workaround introduced by #700. Kevin now supports control-file conditionals :)

data.title: buildsystem: allow customization of config and asset dir
data.body: As requested in #667, this allows customization of `GLOBAL_CONFIG_DIR` and `GLOBAL_ASSET_DIR`.

data.title: Prefix-matching for tests
data.body:
When running tests, like ```util::tests::constinit_vector``` only one test is run. 
This enables to say run test ```util::tests``` to run all tests prefixed with ```util::tests```: 
```
util::tests::constinit_vector
util::tests::enum_
util::tests::init
util::tests::matrix
util::tests::quaternion
util::tests::vector
util::tests::siphash
util::tests::array_conversion
```

This makes testing one module much more convenient.

data.title: lua script api
data.body:
labels: experimental,proofofconcept
needs: liblua5.1-0-dev

I wanted to look into lua and did some experiments how to integrate with c++. I choose the [sol2](https://github.com/ThePhD/sol2) framework, because its a simple header file. For compiling you need the lua 5.1 dev files of your distro. The whole thing are event based hooks, so if theres nothing to during the gameloop, there will be nothing done.

A maintainer should add labels experimental, proofofconcept. This pull request is **not** for merge. The script.cpp is ugly and would need some serious rewriting.

How does it work?
There is a singleton to register lua scriptfiles(you can have more than 1). The hooks we decide to implement are written in c++ and call the scripts via member method. The method does all the work with lua code and change the gamestate if necessary.

example hook:
``` cpp
for(auto script : ScriptSingleton::instance().scripts) {

 script->onResourceChange(this->color,resource,amount,this->resources[resource]);

}
```

I think lua is the better choise for ingame scripting. It has better security than python and I dont think python can be integrated so nicely like a language which was designed as embedded language.

It is a counter proposal to @TheJJ #735

data.title: Buildsystem: blacklisting pythontex more flexible
data.body: fixes #793 by allowing a number at pythontex.

data.title: Update required Cython version to 0.25
data.body: As seen in discussion in https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/issues/792

data.title: Blacklist pythontex3 in the buildsystem

milestone.title: Next release
milestone.description: We have a working Qt GUI and many more features! This release is soooo overdue...

data.body:
This is a revival of #708 so that we also exclude `pythontex3`, which is some kind of a Python interpreter bundled with texlive.

Do it in `buildsystem/modules/FindPython.cmake`.

(This came up through #792)

data.title: doc: add blending mask lookup table
data.body: Thanks to @aap for the discovery :)

data.title: Fix RGB endianness used in pixel transfer
data.body:
Fix pixel transfer format for loading an OpenGL texture from an SDL surface. On Mac, this swaps the red & blue channels (so RGB becomes BGR).

Before:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6141784/24840814/80e402c6-1d6c-11e7-9372-af94b8c4e183.png)

After:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6141784/25029164/a847cb9c-20b2-11e7-93bf-5657d48ec13f.png)

Basically I just copied [this stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/4340330/5257399).

data.title: Monk conversions instead of killings, rebased
data.body:
Supercedes #428. No functional changes (I haven't even tested it beyond compilation & tests!), and @bombadie retains primary commit authorship

I got very bored.

Fixes #375

data.title: Fix asset conversion for HD + Rise of the Rajas (Version 5.x)
data.body:
It is not possible to run OpenAge with current Steam version of Age of
Empires HD + Rise of the Rajas (Version 5.x). The run script fails to
convert the assets saying:
```
WARN [py] You have installed incompatible game version(s):
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + Rise of the Rajas (Version 5.x)
```

The complete run log:
```
INFO [py] launching openage v0.3.0-857-gc9419b8
INFO [py] compiled by GNU 5.4.0
INFO [py] running in DEVMODE
INFO [py] No converted assets have been found
INFO [py] Game specification version file not found.
INFO [py] Converting graphics, interface, metadata, sounds
INFO [py] Will save to 'b'/home/dev/openage/assets''
Could not find any installation directory automatically.
Please enter an AOE2 install path manually.
> /media/dev/ISOIMAGE
WARN [py] You have installed incompatible game version(s):
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + Rise of the Rajas (Version 5.x)
WARN [py] You need at least one of:
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: The Conquerors, Patch 1.0c
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: Forgotten Empires
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD Edition (Version 3.0+)
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + Forgotten Empires (Version 4.0+)
WARN [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + African Kingdoms (Version 4.7+)
 ERR [py] game asset conversion failed
converting from '/media/dev/ISOIMAGE'
```

The provided image path is the Steam version (2017-03-31) of HD + Rise
of the Rajas + The African Kingdom + The Forgotten Empires.

data.title: ignore compiled QML
data.body: There's a bunch of compiled qml files in my assets folder. I assert that we need to exclude these from version control.

data.title: Fix Age2HD string resources search
data.body:
I did `make run` for the first time, and found that the search for string resources looks in the wrong path. It looks in `resources/resources/`. As a result: no string resources are found, and `driver.py` reaches [this statement](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/6488818ff0412f5e7f1df7a1af724b79decf657f/openage/convert/driver.py#L54):

```python
    if not count:
        raise FileNotFoundError("could not find any language files")
```

I assume this is because [`driver.py` sets `path` to `srcdir["resources"]`](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/6488818ff0412f5e7f1df7a1af724b79decf657f/openage/convert/driver.py#L41), so when `hdlanguagefile.py` adds another `"resources"` into the search path: it fails (there's no such directory as `resources/resources`).

Maybe the better place to make this fix is inside `driver.py`, but IIRC I briefly tried that and it didn't help.

If someone feels strongly about making the fix in `driver.py` instead: I can double-check whether that change would work. but I would need to know what to delete to ensure that `make run` will attempt again the search for string resources.

My assets come from Age2HD (I used `steamcmd.sh` to install the Windows game to my Mac. it was hard because `steamcmd.sh` is a travesty):

```
INFO [py] Game version(s) detected:
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + African Kingdoms (Version 4.7+)
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + Forgotten Empires (Version 4.0+)
…
INFO [py] asset conversion complete; asset version: 6
```

Also I made the asset search skip some files (`_packages`, and macOS's `.ds_store`) that are known to not be string resource languages.

data.title: Integrate Rise of Rome (AoK prequel)
data.body:
@TheJJ asked me back in january to join forces to speed up developing
OpenAge. Unfortunately, life had other plans for me so hence the 3
months delay.

I think it would be a nice thing to have to be able to provide support
for the prequels of AoE II as well. In my opinion, the original AoE is
very limited due to lots of boring micromanagement. I would like to help
to integrate the expansion to AoE: Rise of Rome.

Let me know what you guys think or what you need help with the most so
we can improve OpenAge together and maybe integrate the prequels in the
future :D

Some things I've come up with:

To integrate the prequels OpenAge either needs to provide multiple setup
options in the configuration scripts for the specified build target
(e.g. --game=[AoK|RoR|AoC]) or the game engine needs to be upgraded to
support different genie game engines on-the-fly.

Some of the issues that need to be resolved:

* The Genie game engine in all AoE II games are very different from the
  original game engine used in AoE I and RoR (especially with
  path-finding).
* Verify whether the file format of original game assets in AoE II are
  compatible with the original game assets (otherwise, we need to
  upgrade the assets converter to also support RoR).

Related:
* AOE I support: #808 
* SWGB support: #421

I had some (unrelated) local changes that I needed to make in order to help it find the string resources in my assets folder. it was looking in `resources/resources/…`, so I had to remove the dupe. here's my local changes in case anybody cares:

``` diff
@@ -21,13 +21,18 @@ def read_age2_hd_fe_stringresources(stringres, path):
 
     count = 0

     # multiple string files in the program source dir
     for lang in path.list():
         try:
             if lang == b'_common':
                 continue
+            if lang == b'_packages':
+                continue
+            if lang.lower() == b'.ds_store'.lower():
+                continue
 
-            langfilename = ["resources", lang.decode(),
+            langfilename = [lang.decode(),
                             "strings", "key-value",
                             "key-value-strings-utf8.txt"]
```

data.title: doc on Formations
data.body:
This PR aims to summarize all results from #705 which @Piruzzolo and me have discovered. I think nobody wants to read through the lengthy discussion to get something done.

- [x] Principles used in AoE 2 
- [x] Formation structure
  - [x] Land Units
  - [x] Ships
- [x] Subformation structure
- [x] Formation Types
- [x] Limitations in AoE2
- [x] Pseudocode/Algorithm proposal

data.title: Use mandy webinterface for our Kevin CI

milestone.title: Next release
milestone.description: We have a working Qt GUI and many more features! This release is soooo overdue...

data.body:
Not directly related to openage, but [its CI](https://github.com/SFTtech/kevin).
Before reaching the milestone, we want to have the mandy CI webinterface up and running.

Not much more work is needed as @mic-e implemented a minimal and awesome live-view-terminal for the build output.

data.title: File format documentation incomplete
data.body:
I've been working on documenting the .dat files lately, check out:
https://github.com/aap/geniedoc
Sorry this is not a PR but I wanted to compile everything in one place in the same style and didn't want to write it twice. I hope you find it helpful.

data.title: Obfuscate email addresses in `copying.md`
data.body:
Enable contributors to obfuscate the email address they publish in `copying.md`.

Main goal here is to make it less of a target for search engines.

data.title: Entering AOE2 install path manually: "No valid existing directory"
data.body:
```
INFO [py] Will save to 'b'/Users/birch/git/openage/assets''
  Should we call wine to determine an AOE installation? [Y/n]
> n
Could not find any installation directory automatically.
Please enter an AOE2 install path manually.
> /Users/anon/Documents/age2hd/attempt2 
WARN [py] No valid existing directory: /Users/anon/Documents/age2hd/attempt2
```

This is actually a valid directory. Look what happens if I add a trailing slash:

```
Please enter an AOE2 install path manually.
> /Users/anon/Documents/age2hd/attempt2/
converting from '/Users/anon/Documents/age2hd/attempt2'
INFO [py] Game version(s) detected:
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + African Kingdoms (Version 4.7+)
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: The Conquerors, Patch 1.0c
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: Forgotten Empires
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD Edition (Version 3.0+)
INFO [py]  * Age of Empires 2: HD + Forgotten Empires (Version 4.0+)
INFO [py] converting metadata
INFO [py] [0] palette
INFO [py] [1] empires.dat
INFO [py] [2] blendomatic.dat
INFO [py] [3] player color palette
INFO [py] [4] terminal color palette
INFO [py] [5] string resources
```

Here's the part of the code that seems to get confused:

https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/openage/convert/main.py#L303

```python
        if Path(sourcedir).is_dir():
            return sourcedir
        else:
            warn("No valid existing directory: {}".format(sourcedir))
```

I wonder why it doesn't understand that that Path is a directory (unless you add a trailing slash).

data.title: introduce Mac-specific shims for `utimenstat()` and for `stat.st_mtim`
data.body:
`utimenstat()` interprets nullptr as "use current time", so I used POSIX `clock_gettime()` to grab current time.

Apparently [`utimes()` can be used instead of `utimensat()`](https://github.com/mpartel/bindfs/issues/6#issuecomment-42538754), we just needed to convert timespec into a timeval.

Fixed the `st_mtim` problem also. We wanted a "modified timestamp" of type `struct timespec`. [`st_mtimespec` should do the trick](https://gist.github.com/Birch-san/ebca41072b8ade2be0bfbc18b110fb94#file-stat_2_sierra-txt-L79).

Fixes #768

data.title: check for asdf in codecompliance
data.body: basically PR #731, but Btjones711 did not continue.

data.title: Fixing our DoublyLinkedList
data.body:
Our (currently unused) DoublyLinkedList had some real issues.
While writing tests, I discovered many things, but the real interesting things were those, that should have raised a compilation error, but didn't. I guess they didn't, because we defined everything in a header and the functions containing uncompilable code were never called(referenced).

I'm not exactly sure, what we can learn from this.
I would suggest using header files for declaration and a separate file for definition. When trying to create `doubly_linked_list.o` from `doubly_linked_list.cpp`, that should have raised an error.
Besides that: If we keep everything in one header, doesn't that lead to every compilation unit recreating the machine code for that class?

data.title: fix missing braces warnings for subobject initialization
data.body:
See here for more info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14794490/c-stdarray-warning
For some reason my clang kept complaining about `a = {stuff}`, so I went with `a {{stuff}}`.

data.title: doc: Update required Cython version in Build docs.
data.body:
Master now uses Cython `ctypedef`s nested inside `cppclass`es which is only supported from version 0.25 and up.

Cython 0.25 is not currently in the standard package repositories on Ubuntu 16.04, but is available through pip, so I changed the Ubuntu build doc to account for that.

Ref #772

data.title: Make not working
data.body:
I followed the steps for the build procedure, but when I get to "make" in the terminal, it stops at 88% and I get these errors.

![openage_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26680994/24327637/fbe54752-118a-11e7-9703-981c4e32738d.png)

Using Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

How do I proceed?
Thanks

data.title: Enforce proper comment format?
data.body:
The comment style inside libopenage is pretty mixed. Have a look on these comments:
unit_type.h:48:
```
/**
 * UnitType has to main roles:
 *
 * initialise(unit, player) should be called on a unit to give it a type and the required attributes, abilities and initial actions
 * of that type
 *
 * place(unit, terrain, initial position) is called to customise how the unit gets added to the world -- used to setup the TerrainObject location
 *
 * UnitType is connected to a player to allow independent tech levels
 */
class UnitType {
```
unit_type.h:68:
```
        /**
         * gets the parent id of this unit type
         * which is used for village base and gather types
         */
```

path.h:23:
```
/**
 * The data type for movement cost
 */
```
path.h:39:
```
/**
 * Cost comparison for node_pt.
 * Extracts the ptr from the shared_ptr.
 * Calls operator < on Node.
 */
```
All except the last comment lack punctuation. While reading them in source, this does not matter because of the linebreaks. In doxygen, however, simple linebreaks vanish.
The second comment is missing proper capitalization.
I think, the last one is pretty ok. If there is something that deserves a fancy comment, `@param` etc. can be used.
From `code_style/mom.cpp` I thought the fourth comment style was the only way to go, but then, in line 122:
```
private:
        /** links to the story of the game */
        Story *story;
```
(private ?) attributes may be commented in lower-case without punctuation?

So, how strict are we with comment-styles?

data.title: Multiplayer: Shared / Co-Op Mode
data.body:
In the original Age of Empire 2 (never played the HD version) there exists an undocumented "shared" multiplayer mode. When you choose same color, team and civilization for two teams, they can control the same units, have the same buildings, share the same resources etc. I.e. they act/appear as one player in the game, that can be controlled from two persons (more should be possible, but I have never tested).
It would be pretty cool if this is possible in openage too.
